awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: A Unified Framework for IoT Privacy
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart cities, connected vehicles, smart homes, and connected healthcare devices are examples of how the Internet of Things (IoT) are expected to revolutionize our lives in the decades ahead by exploiting a wealth of user-specific data to significantly improve user experiences.  However, sharing of such data can compromise a user's privacy, and this threat to user-privacy has emerged as a critical risk to the widespread adoption of IoT.  This highlights an important and fundamental challenge critical to the Science of Cyber-Physical Systems: even if IoT data is carefully anonymized, significant privacy leaks can occur due to the sheer amount of the data generated and the use of powerful mathematical techniques by an adversary to match current behavior with traces of past user behavior.  This project will develop a systematic approach to understand the fundamental underpinnings of privacy in IoT systems, and develop provably private IoT implementations that are robust to uncertainties in the models.  A key advantage of this approach is that it can achieve provable privacy, i.e., no algorithm can break the privacy of the user.  The project also continues the team's education and engagement of a diverse set of students, including the significant involvement of undergraduate students in the research program, and creates and promotes free and open access educational materials.

The technical problems considered in the project are organized into two main thrusts.  In Thrust 1, the theoretical foundations for IoT privacy are built.  The main goal is to obtain a fundamental understanding of the degree to which the utility of IoT approaches can be maintained while employing privacy-preserving mechanisms to provably prevent an adversary from compromising a user's privacy by matching a given trace to prior user behavior.  Critical to this thrust is achieving robust and model independent design, i.e., achieving perfect privacy with the minimum sets of assumptions about the system and data models. In Thrust 2, to validate the theory and demonstrate the potential impact of the approach, the project leverages the domain expertise of the team to apply the results of Thrust 1 in connected vehicle applications.  More generally, this will indicate the degree to which the data of a given user can be kept private from an interested adversary while still supporting the use of such services.

por.por_cntn:
Internet of Things (IoT) applications such as smart cities, connected vehicles, smart homes, and connected healthcare devices are revolutionizing our lives.  However, the potential loss of privacy is a significant threat to IoT penetration. This leads to a great challenge:  IoT devices will be generating an astounding amount of data every second in the near future, and, even if privacy-protecting mechanisms are employed, significant privacy leaks can occur due to the sheer amount of the data generated and powerful statistical inference techniques available to the potential adversaries.  Such privacy leakage might entail the identification of a device user, the exposure of a user's location, or the inference of an attribute of the user that they wish to keep private.

A main achievement of this project has been to introduce a unifying framework for IoT privacy. The main idea is that a large class of IoT privacy problems can be modeled mathematically as matching and de-noising time-series data. Using this setting, the PIs and the team defined information-theoretic measures of privacy and characterized necessary conditions to achieve perfect privacy, a concept that is rigorously defined in this research. A key advantage of this approach, especially in the face of recent advances in algorithms and computation, is that it can achieve provable privacy, i.e., no algorithm can break the privacy of the user.

The developed theory was used to design privacy mechanisms for different situations. For example, the team considered scenarios were a powerful adversary exploits correlations between users to invade their privacy. The team also extended the analysis to scenarios were adversaries use patterns in users’ data to break anonymous data.

Several applications were considered. In particular, IoT and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) networks can benefit from the algorithms and mechanisms developed in this project to enhance the privacy of their users.  For example, the team applied the developed techniques to privacy for UAVs, which may want to keep delivery locations private for sensitive packages such as healthcare products.   

Throughout the project, the team hired multiple Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) students who have worked on developing a privacy mechanisms for Android devices. Specifically, It has become common for smartphone apps to request access to users' location information to offer various services to the users. However, different apps require different granularities of location information in order to be able to perform their expected service. With the help of REU students, we devised various mechanisms to minimize location privacy leakage to apps by obfuscating the location information provided to the apps to the levels that are required for their operation without exposing extra location information.
